title: What will the 7-day average number of new cases of COVID-19 be in Texas for the week ending 13 June 2020, as reported by the Texas Department of State Health Services?
preds:
arrr, come on. Edit: oh, well... 2,331 as of 13 June 2020.
7-day Average 1779.7,
150 cases or 2,000 tests away from the threshold - over the whole week. (21 cases or 300 tests per day)... I just hope the jury will take any revision into account, whenever it will be reported. And that all revisions will be embodied by 14 June 5pm EDT, the time of resolution. Edit 2: one last time A projection until resolution:
[estimate] daily cases TX | daily tests TX || 7day trailing average positivity rate |||
07.06.2020 1425? | 7169? || 6,92% |||
08.06.2020 638 | 19,870 || 6.87% ||| 1,031.5 2 day average 07 June 2020 through 08 June 2020
09.06.2020 1,637 | 27,039 || 6.39% ||| 1,233.3 3 day average 07 June 2020 through 09 June 2020
10.06.2020 2,504 | 13,732 || 7.16% ||| 1,551.0 4 day average 07 June 2020 through 10 June 2020
11.06.2020 1,826 | 43,233 || 6.79% ||| 1,606.0 5 day average 07 June 2020 through 11 June 2020
12.06.2020 2,097 | 20,637 || 7.12% ||| 1,687.7 6 day average 07 June 2020 through 12 June 2020
13.06.2020 2331 | 33362|| 7.05% ||| 1779.7 7 day average 07 June 2020 through 13 June 2020 Daily positivity rate as of 12 June 2020: 6.99% Total span width: 2,504 (as of 10 June) minus 638 (as of 08 June) = 1,866 (74,5% of the peak value). I think I understand the reason better now why this question was "too difficult to forecast" from the beginning.
From the question it is clear that the first day counting would be 07 June 2020. On this day, there were only 7,169 tests taken, which is ridiculously little for a state like Texas, and is only 27.2% of the average daily tests taken during 08 June to13 June 2020 (average: 26,312). Testing on 07 June 2020 is also 36,064 or 83,4% below the peak testing during this episode of 43,233 tests on 11 June 2020. I consider this one number of tests on 07 June 2020 a near-total breakdown. If I had know this when I first forecasted this on 11 May 2020, I had certainly not answered this question.
The effect to it is simple: we were asked to predict a 7-day average, where only 6 serious values are being taken. When one value is missing more or less, you are in effect asked to predict the 85%-value of a 7-day average. The low testing figure 07 June 2020 (7,169) then obviously fed into the results of the next day (638 confirmed cases 08 June 2020). Therefore, the total span width (2,504 (as of 10 June) minus 638 (as of 08 June) = 1,866 (74,5% of the peak value)) was larger than the highest bucket threshold in the question. If we leave the dismal figures in question (7,169 tests as of 07 June 2020, 638 cases as of 08 June 2020) out of consideration, the question resolution is pretty much crystal clear:
1,970 cases on average for the six days 07 June plus 09 June through 13 June 2020, means highest bucket.
26,312 tests on average for the six days 08 June through 13 June 2020.
7.49% average positivity rate. Too bad I did not know that on 11 May 2020. Never lean on government/state data. Don't take a train where it depends on the mood of the train conductor if he's going to stick to the road map, and if he is going to stop at your train station or not today.
Yikes, June 11 is 2097. Another two days at 2K and we are on the bubble. So I'll go all in as I've spent so much time in the other bucket. Poor TX.

6 down, one to go [1]:
7th: 1425
8th: 638
9th: 1637
10th: 2504
11th: 1826
12th: 2097  Current average: 1688 (rounded up) Tomorrow's number will need to be greater than 2473 to have the average end up in the top bucket. Going to put it all in the lower bucket. [1] https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/ed483ecd702b4298ab01e8b9cafc8b83

The average will be >1800 if the number of cases for 6/13 is 2473 or over. I set up a normal dist for the last 3 days using the mean and sd of the last 3 days of data, and got that there's an 83% chance we stay below 1800. I did the same for the last 7 days of data and got that there's an 89% chance we stay below 1800. I'll take the average of those.

A projection until resolution:
[estimate] daily cases TX | daily tests TX || 7day trailing average positivity rate |||
07.06.2020 1425? | 7169? || 6,92% |||
08.06.2020 638 | 19,870 || 6.87% ||| 1,031.5 2 day average 07 June 2020 through 08 June 2020
09.06.2020 1,637 | 27,039 || 6.39% ||| 1,233.3 3 day average 07 June 2020 through 09 June 2020
10.06.2020 2,504 | 13,732 || 7.16% ||| 1,551.0 4 day average 07 June 2020 through 10 June 2020
11.06.2020 1,826 | 43,233 || 6.79% ||| 1,606.0 5 day average 07 June 2020 through 11 June 2020
12.06.2020 2,097 | 20,637 || 7.12% ||| 1,687.7 6 day average 07 June 2020 through 12 June 2020
13.06.2020 [2,555] | [51,000] || 7.05% ||| 1,811.7 7 day average 07 June 2020 through 13 June 2020 Daily positivity rate as of 12 June 2020: 10.16% Opinions welcome... 2,480 for tomorrow 13 June 2020 a must. I'll go for it.

This is a nail-biter. My estimate edged down just a bit to 1778 (from 1783). I'm already assuming that cases continue their current trend of the 7-day average increasing by about 49-50/day, so that gives an extra ~150 in the next 2 days (=50*2 + 50*1).  We would need to see an excess of 153 over the next two days for the June 13 7-day average to be over 1800. The daily standard deviation is about 388. I'm not sure how to do that math (I would appreciate guidance if you know), but for one day that would be something like 35% (or 22% if I assume no continuation of the trend).  For 2 days I would assume that it is a little lower.  So I'm going to call it 75/25.
I can't see the next couple of days being low enough to make the moving average less than 1800.

This has been a fun one. Adjusting based on Houston Chronicle and NYTimes articles citing 1,902 cases on 6/11. Official ArcGis page hasn't been updated... Average for next two days would have to be ≤1,364.33 to end up at 7DMA <1,800.  Given that only only 1 out of 11 of past days have been below that level, I'm all-in at ≥1,800.

In every Friday/Saturday weekend, save one, since May 1st/2nd, the number of new cases reported is higher than the Thursday before or the Sunday after. The exception was Memorial Day weekend, in which this trend was inverted. Additionally, over the same time period, the number of new cases reported was higher on the Saturday as opposed to the Friday 5 out of 6 times (which is where I'm getting 15%). I suspect that this is because of behavioral factors.  A large number of the cases are being attributed to meatpacking and prisons, https://www.texastribune.org/2020/06/08/texas-coronavirus-cases-prisons-meatpacking-plants/ , but the Meatpacking industry has resisted testing until mid May. https://www.texastribune.org/2020/05/13/texas-jbs-meatpacking-plant-rejects-state-efforts-coronavirus-test . Given that Texas is experiencing a backlog in their testing, which is taking up to 4 weeks in some cases, https://www.texastribune.org/2020/06/10/texas-coronavirus-testing-mobile-sites/ , I predict we are likely to see numbers well above 1800 this weekend, closer to 2100.
The average for the past week has been about 1700 cases per day when looking at actual numbers from Texas

The Governors plan in Texas to open businesses to 75%, no real social distancing measures by the State and no mask regulations will lead to a steady increase of cases in Texas- similar to New York City in April, but will be condensed in the multiple Metropolitan areas. Due to the pseudo-political stance taken by many that masks are against their civil liberties, I believe COVID-19 will continue to spread rapidly- specifically in counties and cities that have no local mandates.
Terrifying figures from Texas this week.
People are just not sticking with staying home. Texans think they are special
As of 6/11 the 7 day moving average is nearly 1700 and increasing rapidly.  The 3 day average is 2000.
Hit Cases by County button then Trends in pick list. Look on left side.
Under trends for Texas Health Dept it shows 1826 cases a day on the 11th.
The cases have been growing and restriction are easy. Protest and Labor Day cases are still emerging so there is nothing in favor in a drop in cases in Texas
It’s growing exponentially at this point.
Should end up between 1,350 and 1,800.  UNLESS we get more than 4,570 positives in the next couple of days. Which is definitely possible. Hence still hedging on the more than 1,800 bucket.

Do the math.
1,800 cases x 7 days = 12,600
c. 8000 cases in the first five days. 
c. 4,500+ cases required in the last 2 days to clear the threshold for "More than 1,800"
c. 3,600 cases in the parallel period of the weekly cycle last week.
c. 3,100 cases in the parallel period the week before that.

Given the slope of Texas' trend right now, coupled with recent events that have hampered efforts at social distancing, there is very good reason to believe that Texas' daily average new case count will increase -- most likely beyond 1,800.

5 of the 7 days down [1]:
7th: 1425
8th: 638
9th: 1637
10th: 2504
11th: 1826 Current average: 1606 Looking back on my original approach to using Sweden as a model for TX, they have seen an uptick in cases over the last week, reaching a higher range of 700 - 1000 cases a day, with a spike for a day at 2.2k. I tripled it in my original estimate, which makes me think that TX, with its similar social distancing rules, could be seeing a minimum of 2.1 - 3k cases per day. Yikes. Again, though movement to those new plateaus tend to be spiky, so I am going sit tight where I am. [1] https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/ed483ecd702b4298ab01e8b9cafc8b83
Reopening the state will only lead to an increase in the number of cases of Covid-19

Thank you @Maarten for pointing out an error: I was relying on a data source (worldometer) that doesn't match the Texas DSHS website exactly despite quoting it as the data source. I've gone back and corrected my calculations with DSHS data. Although the differences in individual days were sometimes large, the 7 day averages did not change materially.  However, the daily totals continue to grow, and have exceeded my forecasts most days this week, so I'm updating my estimate.  I now estimate we'll end at a 7-day average of 1783. I'm assuming that our recent trend of 7-day average continues increasing at around 50/day. To exceed 1800 there would need to be 122 cases above this trend which is well within the range of recent variation.
Would need an average of 2285 per day over the next two days in order to break past 1800.

1,826 as of 11 June 2020. Now it gets tricky. We're above the final average threshold but still need to see two days that average well above 2,300 to be sure for the upper range case. For the certain perpetual reasons I assume this will unfortunately happen. As there is no number of tests available as of now, I take an arbitrary assumption of 32,000 test instead to feed my projection. In case there is another day count of 2,500 to 2,600 tomorrow, the steep upward trend would be confirmed and the daily cases 13 June around 2,000 would be sufficient for the last bucket, however one would still not be out of the woods completely. I lean on @chiefthe 's observation that Mondays are the lowest days of the week and on we'll have no completely outlandish results left. All depends now on how frightened the TX Health Department became from yesterday's figure 2,504, and how fast and seriously they increase testing. Today's actual No. of tests will determine which way they go and if there is a new trend in testing capacity which may result in yet more higher case counts. A projection until resolution:
[estimate] daily cases TX | daily tests TX || 7day trailing average positivity rate |||
07.06.2020 1425? | 7169? || 6,92% |||
08.06.2020 638 | 19,870 || 6.87% ||| 1,031.5 2 day average 07 June 2020 through 08 June 2020
09.06.2020 1,637 | 27,039 || 6.39% ||| 1,233.3 3 day average 07 June 2020 through 09 June 2020
10.06.2020 2,504 | 13,732 || 7.16% ||| 1,551.0 4 day average 07 June 2020 through 10 June 2020
11.06.2020 1,826 | 43,233 || 6.79% ||| 1,606.0 5 day average 07 June 2020 through 11 June 2020
12.06.2020 [2,444] | [50,000] || 6.17% ||| 1,745.7 6 day average 07 June 2020 through 12 June 2020
13.06.2020 [2,555 | [51,000] || 6.23% ||| 1,861.3 7 day average 07 June 2020 through 13 June 2020 EDIT: I inserted the actual number of tests (43,233 tests as of 11 June 2020) and the effect on the coming days' 7d trailing positivity rate.
Bumped up my forecast due to the recent increase in cases
Been trending towards 1500 since early May.  Now trending towards 1475.
Very slight update. Looks like the protests/lack of distancing are starting to be felt.

New cases yesterday highest ever at 2504. Need new cases to be above 2132 the coming three days to be more than 1800 for a seven days average. Still believing between 1350 and 1800 to be most likely, but readjusting a bit toward the upper bucket.
Clearly my model and I are confused about this one, so I'll straddle.
My error in my model. Sorry for TX.

First four days in the week [1]:
7th: 1425
8th: 638
9th: 1637
10th: 2504  Current average: 1551 HT to @SE_Meyer for his thoughts and analysis regarding the backlogged testing. I am hesitant to go as far, as I have seen high spikes in looking at other states' data that doesn't hang around. Even if they are moving to a new plateau, the movement there tends to be spiky rather than consistent, so while TX may be headed to a 2k+ per day average, it may not hold that average until next week.  Hedging a bit back into the above 1800. [1] https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/ed483ecd702b4298ab01e8b9cafc8b83

10 June 2020, much anticipated. Turnout of 2,504 is the highest on record so far and might contain some of the positive tests which have, for technical reasons, not been reported on 07 June 2020 through 09 June 2020. After reconciliation of daily test attribution, there's a more consistent picture: 19,233 of the tests as of 09 June 2020 have been re-attributed to 08 June. The most striking point: Daily positivity rate hit 18.2% as of 10 June 2020 (2,504 positives out of 13,732 new tests), as tests/testing kits have obviously been very scarce in TX lately and too many infections have remained undetected for too long; this opens up likely paths for possible new gloomy scenarios on the high end. Each of today's confirmed case will have worked, traveled and gathered for two to three days and set free a tiny avalanche of new infections in a chain reaction. 
Therefore, re-re-adjusting to 100%. A projection until resolution:
[estimate] daily cases TX | daily tests TX || 7day trailing average positivity rate |||
07.06.2020 1425? | 7169? || 6,92% |||
08.06.2020 638 | 19,870 || 6.87% ||| 1,031.5 2 day average 07 June 2020 through 08 June 2020
09.06.2020 1,637 | 27,039 || 6.39% ||| 1,233.3 3 day average 07 June 2020 through 09 June 2020
10.06.2020 2,504 | 13,732 || 7.16% ||| 1,551.0 4 day average 07 June 2020 through 10 June 2020
11.06.2020 [2,222] | [49,000] || 6.79% ||| 1,685.2 5 day average 07 June 2020 through 11 June 2020
12.06.2020 [2,232] | [50,000] || 6.16% ||| 1,776.3 6 day average 07 June 2020 through 12 June 2020
13.06.2020 [2,242] | [51,000] || 6.19% ||| 1,842.9.1 7 day average 07 June 2020 through 13 June 2020

There is an increase in the numbers and the positivity rate in Texas.  Should easily do a 7DMA of 1,500 for the week ending 13th June. I am still keeping a 60% on more than 1,800 because I have been heavy on the 1,350 - 1,800 all along.  Will check and revise soon.

First three days in the week:
7th: 1637 
8th: 638 
9th: 1425 Current average: 1233 Monday's tend to be the lowest days of the week for Texas over the last couple weeks, so we probably won't see more low values. There have only been four days over 1800 overall, so unless cases pick up significantly in the next couple days, an 1800 average won't be possible. [1] https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/ed483ecd702b4298ab01e8b9cafc8b83

1,637 09 June 2020, much lower turnout than expected... I still think some reassessment for plausibility from TX DSHS will follow for at least two days in consideration.
"Limes" case as below: A projection until resolution:
[estimate] daily cases TX | daily tests TX || 7day trailing average positivity rate |||
07.06.2020 1425? | 7169? || 6,92% |||
08.06.2020 638? | 638? || 7.83% ||| 1,031.5 2 day average 07 June 2020 through 08 June 2020
09.06.2020 1,637 | 46,272 || 6.39% ||| 1,233.3 3 day average 07 June 2020 through 09 June 2020
10.06.2020 [2,212] | [48,000] || 5.75% ||| 1,478.0 4 day average 07 June 2020 through 10 June 2020
11.06.2020 [2,222] | [49,000] || 5.56% ||| 1,626.8 5 day average 07 June 2020 through 11 June 2020
12.06.2020 [2,232] | [50,000] || 5.15% ||| 1,727.7 6 day average 07 June 2020 through 12 June 2020
13.06.2020 [2,242] | [51,000] || 5.38% ||| 1,801.1 7 day average 07 June 2020 through 13 June 2020 More than 2,225 cases on average required for each of the remaining four days to get beyond 1,800 on 13 June 2020. Strong testing (>50,000 per day), a revision of 7/8 June's figures tomorrow still could drive daily cases to 2,500+ on 10 June 2020. However, it's getting less likely.

So we have 935 for sunday and 638 for monday.
So we need 1575 on average for the next 5 days to have a minimum of 1350 on a 7 day average. Could happen, have to adjust daily. Depending on how far today’s nr’s will be from the 1575, I’m going to give % to 900-1350. If it’s <1200 I might even go all in.

Whhatttt? You kiddin' me? Zero tests so far reported for Mon 8 Jun2020, zero confirmed cases? What's wrong with reporting in TX? I wonder how on earth that will come to a meaningful resolution... I don't like to quote myself, but: "[...] only downside risk I see 1) one total day count until 13 June 2020 missing out due to no tests or technical issues, therefore the relatively low value(s) 1,425 as of 07 June or others would potentially gain weight (has not happened in TX historical data yet)." (Jun 8, 2020 08:42AM) By the way, Texas will have daily maximum temperatures in the 30s°C (85 to 95°F) in the next few days and likely loads of hours of intense sunshine. It is still unclear to which degree UV rays, humidity and temperature or climate more generally influence the lifetime/half-life of the virus. This is a factor that I have not considered so far. I guess the coming days will, in that respect, also be a large-scale field experiment. I wonder if a possible correlation can be singled out for TX from the case counts in June.
If now the cases magically disappear from TX's reporting, maybe POTUS was right in the end to expect that the virus will "magically disappear", too? And what about the more frequent use of air conditioning, that seems certain to me to promote the virus spread, on the other hand? I'm confused.

My estimate is 1575 (1430 - 1690).  So unless there is a step function up in new cases I think we're a lock for the 1350-1800 bucket. Yesterday was unexpectedly low 935 even for a Sunday so I don't see evidence to suggest a big step function is in the works. Here are my estimates for my rapid growth scenario. If I see it consistently running above these levels then I'll re-evaluate my probabilities. 
7-Jun	935 (actual)
8-Jun	1235
9-Jun	1662
10-Jun	1826
11-Jun	2246
12-Jun	2240
13-Jun	1685
Much closer to the date.  Was 1443 for the last week.

Yesterday, something strange happened.
The good news is: there were 1,425 confirmed cases only.
The bad news: there were 7,169 tests only, a drop of 30,532 or 80% vs. 06 June 2020
Positivity rate: 19.9%...
Today's figures must give us a clue. A projection until resolution:
[estimate]	daily cases TX | daily tests TX || 7day trailing average positivity rate |||	
07.06.2020	1425      |   7169       ||   6,92%	|||	
08.06.2020	[2,020]      |   [40,000]     ||   6.87%	|||	1,722.5	2 day average 07 June 2020 through 08 June 2020
09.06.2020	[1,776]      |   [35,000]     ||   6.25%	|||	1,740.3	3 day average 07 June 2020 through 09 June 2020
10.06.2020	[1,836]      |   [42,000]     ||   5.69%	|||	1,764.3	4 day average 07 June 2020 through 10 June 2020
11.06.2020	[1,861]      |   [45,000]     ||   5.46%	|||	1,783.6	5 day average 07 June 2020 through 11 June 2020
12.06.2020	[1,861]      |   [43,000]     ||   5.09%	|||	1,796.5	6 day average 07 June 2020 through 12 June 2020
13.06.2020	[1,861]      |   [50,000]     ||   5.21%	|||	1,805.7	7 day average 07 June 2020 through 13 June 2020 It is getting very close again. However, I see large upside risk in 1) actual positivity rate being higher, rather close to 10 per cent 2) unconfirmed tests as of 07 June 2020 being confirmed 08 June 2020 (higher catch-up) 3) something unknown related to street protests; only downside risk I see 1) one total day count until 13 June 2020 missing out due to no tests or technical issues, therefore the relatively low value(s) 1,425 as of 07 June or others would potentially gain weight (has not happened in TX historical data yet). We'd have totally different (and much worse) picture, if 7 d trailing average positivity remains at around 7 per cent (in a feedback loop) with the testing intensity as projected above (daily tests TX estimates):
2,766 confirmed cases | 7.29% positivity (08 June 2020)
2,552 confirmed cases | 7.03% positivity (09 June 2020)
2,954 confirmed cases | 6.91% positivity (10 June 2020)
3,111 confirmed cases | 7.15% positivity (11 June 2020)
3,075 confirmed cases | 7.13% positivity (12 June 2020)
3,567 confirmed cases | 7.43% positivity (13 June 2020) It seems pretty much (I hope it's not due to a calculation fail...), but this my worst case scenario for TX until 13 June 2020. 7 day average number of new cases reported in Texas would then be as high as 2,779.
Moving more emphasis on the last bucket - more than 1,800.
Going to turn the dial hard here for at least a day or two...up-trend on 7DMA pretty solid.
It appears the Memorial Day holiday drove an increase in new cases in TX. If so, this rate could persist for the remainder of the forecast period.

As of today, the average is sitting at 1602 new cases per day [1]. It is tough to see if this is an increasing trend or a new plateau. There are two values above 1800 per day over the last week (1949 on 5/31, and 1940 on today-- 6/6). Assuming a plateau due to the change in state-wide guidance and maintaining my original estimate for now. [1] https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/ed483ecd702b4298ab01e8b9cafc8b83

On 08 June 2020, the last value below "1,649 (04 June 2020) new cases per day" will stop to be included into the 7 d average, namely the 593 new cases of 01 June 2020. If there are no new outlier data below 1,000 cases per day, and if the next three daily figures (06 through 08 June 2020) will be reported in a range of 1,650 to 2,000, the 7 d average will jump to more than 1,700 cases on 08 June 2020 pretty certainly. I re-post some thoughts about testing in Texas... The quota of tests in TX compared to total tests in the US has still not improved much, in the past few days TX did not expand testing as fast as the US in total, so their share in testing has sunk instead, from 5.59% to 5.52%.
daily tests US daily tests TX share ( TX/US) || total tests US total tests TX share ( TX/US)
403,791 | 18,166 | 4.50% || 17,340,682 | 970,031 | 5.59% Mon 1 June 2020
417,156 | 16,193 | 3.88% || 17,757,838 | 986,224 | 5.55% Tue 2 June 2020
457,112 | 20,544 | 4.49% || 18,214,950 | 1,006,768 | 5.53% Wed 3 June 2020
465,579 | 31,787 | 6.83% || 18,680,529 | 1,038,555 | 5.56% Thu 4 June 2020
550,915 | 23,021 | 4.18% || 19.231.444 | 1,061,576 | 5.52% Fri 5 June 2020 Texas has executed 1,061,576 tests as of 5 Jun 2020, while their share of population suggests they should have done at least 1,640,000 tests (a lag of ~ 578,500 tests as of now...).
Prudent testing would require them to have 650k more tests done, which at the official 7d average ("Seven Day Positive Test Rate") of 6.03% would result in 39,195 additional new cases in the short term. The problem is getting bigger and bigger, it is getting more difficult to contain, even if TX starts a massive testing campaign immediately. If they go on like this, they will likely count 119k cases on 30 Jun 2020, and, since growth in cases will accelerate then, 190k on 15 July 2020.
It appears the holiday gatherings have influenced the totals.

Backing off of the extremes here.  Plateauing a bit. ---6/4 update follows--- I feel the the following are very strong signals for the upper two buckets, and am shifting a lot of weight there.: 1. Major increase in positives is not a function of increase in tests. Total tests have been essentially flat [1], so %positive is increasing
2. Significant new transmission via demonstrations against police violence [2]
3. Municipalities strongly encouraging demonstrators to get tested––what is important here is that even if there has NOT been significant new transmission at demonstrations, simply encouraging a large group of people to go get tested would mean uncovering new asymptomatic/low-symptomatic cases that would not otherwise have been tested [3] A linear forecast of last several weeks would suggest that we end the subject timeframe in the 1,500 realm for 7DMA. But if we look at even very modest exponential growth, we could easily be above 2,000. If over the next few days we maintain a floor ≥1,000 and start hitting numbers ≥2,000, I'll be quickly shifting more weight into upper end here. [1] https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/0d8bdf9be927459d9cb11b9eaef6101f
[2] https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/03/us/us-coronavirus-protests/index.html
[3] https://www.statesman.com/news/20200603/austin-protesters-should-get-tested-for-coronavirus-health-officials-say

Readjusting to current data. Has been trending upward, bit might have reached a plateau the last couple of weeks. If a plateau has been reached I would expect it to stay there for a while before going down, so I don't believe Texas will see a significant drop in new cases next week.

Slight adjustment. Logic from 6/4 update below still applies... ––– ——— I feel the the following are very strong signals for the upper two buckets, and am shifting a lot of weight there.: 1. Major increase in positives is not a function of increase in tests. Total tests have been essentially flat [1], so %positive is increasing
2. Significant new transmission via demonstrations against police violence [2]
3. Municipalities strongly encouraging demonstrators to get tested––what is important here is that even if there has NOT been significant new transmission at demonstrations, simply encouraging a large group of people to go get tested would mean uncovering new asymptomatic/low-symptomatic cases that would not otherwise have been tested [3] A linear forecast of last several weeks would suggest that we end the subject timeframe in the 1,500 realm for 7DMA. But if we look at even very modest exponential growth, we could easily be above 2,000. If over the next few days we maintain a floor ≥1,000 and start hitting numbers ≥2,000, I'll be quickly shifting more weight into upper end here. Revising for more numbers in Texas

Yesterday’s commentary below. Dialing up the high end slightly.  ——— I feel the the following are very strong signals for the upper two buckets, and am shifting a lot of weight there.: 1. Major increase in positives is not a function of increase in tests. Total tests have been essentially flat [1], so %positive is increasing 
2. Significant new transmission via demonstrations against police violence [2] 
3. Municipalities strongly encouraging demonstrators to get tested––what is important here is that even if there has NOT been significant new transmission at demonstrations, simply encouraging a large group of people to go get tested would mean uncovering new asymptomatic/low-symptomatic cases that would not otherwise have been tested [3] A linear forecast of last several weeks would suggest that we end the subject timeframe in the 1,500 realm for 7DMA. But if we look at even very modest exponential growth, we could easily be above 2,000. If over the next few days we maintain a floor ≥1,000 and start hitting numbers ≥2,000, I'll be quickly shifting more weight into upper end here. They are currently hitting about 1,000 new cases a day, with over 55,000 confirmed cases at time of forecast, with 1,519 fatalities.  The positivity rate has tailed off at around 5-6%.  While Texas is large and lends itself to easy social distancing even without legislation (wide open spaces as opposed to densely populated areas), as a broad generalisation, I anticipate that they will still congregate for things like church services etc. That said, if people that they know are seriously ill or killed from the virus, then they may be more willing to believe in the benefits of distancing.

Texas seem to have had quite few cases per capita as of yet. The risk of larger spread seem high. While it does seem the number of cases seem pretty stable around 1000-1800 (some deviation), one single event between 14-28 of May can spread to virus to previous unaffected clusters of the population and give a sharp rise in cases.
It might be the case the spread of the virus, like the flu, is halted in the summer. But while Vietnam has a low number of cases, Brazil has a high number. I don't put much confidence in this making a huge difference in the coming two weeks in Texas in any case.

As far as I interpret the numbers, Texas has been dramatically under-tested so far.
With a population of 27.862 mn (as of 2016), it is the second most populated state second only to CA, and it represents roughly 8.5 % of US total population (326.693mn).
The number of tests in Texas so far is 721k and represents only 5.4 % of the total tests (13.399mn as of Thursday 21 May 2020).
Just to catch up with the average, the number of total tests in Texas has to increase by just short of 60 % or roughly 430k to 1.151mn. As an emerging hot spot, one would rather expect the share of tests to rise to above average in order to get ahead of the curve. With about 53,552 positive tests as of now and an underlying positivity rate of 7.25%, a return to a normal, precautious  and prudent testing strategy in Texas and 500k more tests in the near future, this could easily bring to light some 68% or 36,250 additional confirmed cases in the near term.
May 20= 945 new cases. Appears to have slowed its ascent.
I revised my forecast downward now that antibody tests are being separated out from positive tests.

If week over week growth stays between ~2% and 12% over the next three weeks, the forecast should land in the 1350 - 1800 bucket.  Adjusting my forecast up to account for a higher probability there will be a more than 1800 cases.
May 19= 1411 new cases. Appears to have resumed climbing.

In general, it looks to me like other major outbreaks (such as the UK) follow the same general pattern: first, a massive early climb while testing ramps up as we discover all the cases that had been building up over previous days and weeks. We then have a slowly declining plateau, as testing numbers continue to climb rapidly, but new cases (either new infections, or stragglers from the initial outbreak) get harder and harder to find. The plateau oscillates quite a bit, which I think is a combination of 1) day to day randomness in testing and infections, and  2) the fact that each large outbreak is an ensemble of smaller city- and town-level outbreaks, each of which probably look more like your classic logistic/epidemic curve. A month out is hard to know, but I think it's very unlikely that cases will have crashed down by then, especially with some uptick in growth with coming unlocks, and the lack of a ROK-style eradication capability. I think that it's mostly likely it will be oscillating around the current value (just below 1300), with enough variance to put it in either band. I expect a slow downward trend from here, so biased accordingly. If something goes really wrong during the unlock, and we have a new super-spreader event, it's possible it could spike up into the top band, but I think (hope?) that's unlikely.

Based on the last 7 weeks of 7-day averages (trending up from 600-800 range up to 1260), it would seem that the cases would be in the 1350-1800 range by the middle of June. However, it is hard to assume this is a "linear" trend.  You could make an argument for cases increasing more "exponentially", given the state opening up and the increased testing across the board. You could make an argument on the other side, that maybe Texas has "peaked" (although that seems unlikely) and cases will be lower in a month. I'm going to lean more heavily on the upper ends of ranges.
Moving to a less aggressive assumption assuming nearing the peak at this time.
